repnme.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis - HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the HIV/AIDS Prevention and
            Control Project for St. Kitts and Nevis were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            project design should match the country context and the
            capacity available in-country. Using a template model that
            may have worked in other countries creates implementation
            delays and unrealistic expectations. This applies especially
            to commitment by all stakeholders, especially Civil Society
            Organization (CSOs) and to establishing the appropriate
            institutional framework for program implementation. The
            project design could have had more of a capacity building
            and systems development emphasis. Technical and fiduciary
            teams struggle to cope with responsibilities at inception in
            a country that is a first time borrower and where
            collaboration between more than one ministry is key to
            successful implementation. The capacity to implement
            monitoring and evaluation (M&E) must be identified and
            addressed at the design stage and a budget assigned to it.
            This is especially important when no baseline data are
            available and need to be collected within the first year of
            the project. If that is not possible then proxy data should
            be used so that performance and outcomes can be measured and
            monitored. The ability to retain technical and fiduciary
            staff after project closure is a necessary condition to
            guarantee operational sustainability. In the case of St.
            Kitts and Nevis, the skills and experience of trained staff
            were retained by absorbing the staff in the Government
            establishment and therefore staff will be available to
            continue controlling the spread of the HIV and mitigate its impact.

St. Kitts and Nevis - HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and Control Project

11575032.trustfund:
TF026626-PHRD-DOMINICA: CARIBBEAN
            HIV/AIDS PREVENTION CONTROL PROJECT,TF026634-PHRD-ST. KITTS AND NEVIS:
            CARIBBEAN HIV/AIDS PREVENTION CONTROL

repnme.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis - HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and Control Project : amendment to the loan agreement and
            loan restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This loan restructuring for the St.
            Kitts and Nevis HIV/AIDS prevention and control project
            would: restate the development objective of the project and
            revise the monitoring and evaluation framework; ii) simplify
            the project design by realigning project components; iii)
            update costs of project activities; introduce changes to the
            institutional arrangements to clarify roles and
            responsibilities of the implementing agencies involved in
            project execution and strengthen capacity for project
            implementation; and, extend the project closing date by one
            year to allow adequate time for completion of project
            activities. These changes will require amendments to the
            loan agreement.

5087355.trustfund:
TF026634-PHRD-ST. KITTS AND NEVIS:
            CARIBBEAN HIV/AIDS PREVENTION CONTROL

repnme.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis - HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and Control Project aims to support selected activities of
            St. Kitts and Nevis' Strategic Plan for the National
            Response to HIV/AIDS. There are four components to the
            project. The advocacy and behavior change component will
            assist the government to create a favorable legal and policy
            environment that protects the rights of persons living with
            HIV/AIDS, and maintain awareness of HIV/AIDS and prevention
            measures. The prevention in high risk groups and general
            population component will finance activities to identify
            high-risk groups, in order to target them with prevention
            and behavioral change interventions. The access to
            treatment, care and support for persons living with HIV/AIDS
            component will support capacity and upgrading current
            services available for providing treatment, care and
            support. The surveillance, epidemiology and research
            component will support a new information system, which will
            protect the confidentiality of medical records assuring
            patient privacy through encrypted technology, and improve
            the quality of the information allowing for cross reference
            analysis from multiple databases. The sustainable management
            response component will support the creation and the initial
            operations of a national council on HIV/AIDS.

2047958.trustfund:
TF026634-PHRD-ST. KITTS AND NEVIS:
            CARIBBEAN HIV/AIDS PREVENTION CONTROL,TF026626-PHRD-DOMINICA: CARIBBEAN
            HIV/AIDS PREVENTION CONTROL PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis - HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and control Project : audit of biomedical waste management practices

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will combat the incidence,
            and impact of HIV/AIDS in St. Kitts and Nevis, and will
            include initiatives by the public, and private sectors to
            strengthen the institutional framework, and build capacities
            responsive to the epidemic. It is important to note that the
            incidence of biomedical wastes within the framework of the
            project, poses adverse environmental impacts, due to the
            inadequate handling of infected materials. This audit of
            biomedical waste management practices, presents its results,
            following an assessment based on information, and review of
            relevant documentation. While some legislation exists, there
            are no specific regulations at the national level on dealing
            with biomedical wastes, thus recommendations are made on
            various elements that could be addressed in future
            regulations. Short-term recommendations are provided for
            immediate implementation, as part of a transition to the
            full implementation of best practices, and a national
            biomedical waste management system. Containers intended for
            infectious wastes should bear the international bio-hazard
            symbol; the UNIVEC safety boxes should be replaced with
            puncture-resistant sharps containers, with lids to prevent
            spillage. Such wastes should be transported to a selected
            central collection point; steps should be taken to phase out
            incineration practices, though as long as these persist, the
            area should be kept clean with appropriate chimneys
            installed, but only infectious waste should be incinerated -
            toxic metals, chlorine, or chlorinated plastics should NOT
            be burned. Incineration practices should be banned in the
            long term, replaced by new efficient treatment technologies.
            Long term recommendations addresses future legislation, and
            regulations on biomedical waste management, considering
            coordination with hazardous (non-biomedical) waste
            management laws, as well as laws dealing with health, and,
            establish national and local authorities to enforce such
            legislation. An institutional policy on biomedical waste
            management should govern the administrative and
            organizational structures of health care facilities, to be
            extended to occupational safety and health issues, waste
            segregation and classification practices.

St. Kitts and Nevis - HIV/AIDS Prevention
            and control Project : audit of biomedical waste management practices
